text: Like, most persons-on-the-street don't maintain a complex taxonomy of right-authoritarianisms. And there’s an actual lineage and cross-pollination from Falangist Spain, Nazi refugees in the Southern Cone, Peronism etc. That's the kind of thing I meant, really.
author: UOJim

text: I think the folk understanding of the classic post-war juntas is as "fascist regimes," don't you? IIRC even Payne, who denied almost any governments except for Mussolini's Italy and the Third Reich were *really fascist*, allowed that there were resemblances.
author: UOJim

text: I worry about it a lot because Inter-War fascism was right-authoritarianism made functional for the new communication channels and transportation networks. Now we have a *newer* set of communication channels, and millennial fascism is, well.
author: UOJim

text: Yeah, the Falklands does. I don’t think I agree about inter-war fascism though. I mean, Hitler's program was a war of extermination to the East from the early 20s. It just took time to put together. Mussolini argued Italy needed to conquer an empire before he ever assumed power.
author: UOJim

text:
Payne IIRC considers an essential distinction between "fascism" and traditional right-authoritarianism to be the interest in a mass base.

i.e. Trad Authoritarians: Shut up and do as your told.
Fascists: Do as you’re told, but be *into it*!

Does Paxton make the same distinction?
author: UOJim

text: See, Payne's kind of a purist. He had fascism on 78rpm shellac and doesn’t consider the Latin-American dictatorships – or even Franco's regime – to be *real* fascism. *Guided* by Payne, though, I think of them as at least fascistic.
author: UOJim

text: I mean, it’s certainly true that Italy kept launching invasions they couldn’t carry off without consulting with Germany, and Germany *dragged* her allies into Russia. But ex ante I’d have thought Our Country Is the True Menz regimes couldn’t keep from fighting *each other*.
author: UOJim

text: Certainly better than Japan coordinated with Germany/Italy. But while the UN did many things better than the Axis - hello, artillery fire control! – it’s also instructive to add up relative populations and GDPs. We had a lot going for us, *and* we were bigger and richer.
author: UOJim

text: I often think I read Paxton, but I think I confuse his book with Stanley G. Payne's. Paxton's book came out later than when I was doing most of my reading on the subject.
author: UOJim

text: Sadly, fascism is a relevant topic every day. Liz's thread is not specifically about the Christchurch atrocity, nor is mine.

author: UOJim

text: Fascism isn’t unique in being emotion-driven. It is *evil* in how it reifies that reflex disgust and elaborates it into programs of extermination. I think failing to recognize this risks underestimating 21st-Century fascism, and I don’t think we can afford to do that.
author: UOJim

text: Yes, fascism seems to flow from a powerful disgust-reaction drive. But all ideologies have an emotional well-spring, because humans are emotional creatures. We were that before we were *thinkers*.
author: UOJim

text: Fascists are not always articulate about their ideology. Nor are they always honest. See Sartre's quote about Antisemites, and the deliberate trolling the Christchurch ringleader inserted into his manifesto. But fascists reveal ideology through their actions and programs.
author: UOJim

text: Nor is fascism "incoherent" or just a bundle of reflexes or what have you. It’s evil, not unintelligible.  Just as white supremacism is a genuine ideology, so is its cousin, fascism. Fascists have beliefs about how society should be ordered. That’s an ideology.
author: UOJim

text: And if you look at the generally agreed heirs of fascism – Spanish Falangism; charismatic Latin-American caudilloism – it gets depressing just how long such regimes could last if they avoided attacking more powerful countries.
author: UOJim

text: And internally, the fascist parties started out by hating liberals, socialists, communists, and designated racial inferiors, and *kept on hating them*. It’s not like the Nazis announced at some point that Swabians weren’t real Germans.
author: UOJim

text: I mean, lol at the Wehrmacht leaving the Romanian Army to secure 4x as much frontage on the flanks of Stalingrad as was doctrinally sound – Operation Uranus was a beautiful thing! But the Romanians went along with it.
author: UOJim

text: It's also kind of weird how well fascist regimes cooperated internationally. You’d think that people who are at bottom rabid ethnonationalists would be at each other's throats. But e.g. Hitler & Mussolini & their authoritarian allies worked reasonably well together.
author: UOJim

text: People. @fredhicks and @boymonster are whipping a squib of *my* off-hand gaming tech into a proper RPG. This is like if Neko Case and Frank Ocean decided to finish one of my half-written songs. I’m over the moon.
